name: Homecare Insurance Limited

products: The Financial Ombudsman Service may be able to consider a dispute with this firm. Find out how to complain.
The Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS) may be able to compensate customers if this firm fails. See how to claim compensation.
Read about how this firm may be able to hold or control money from its customers

other_note.title: Advising on P2P Agreements
note: This is a firm that is given permission to provide regulated products and services

This firm also has permission to advise on P2P agreements. Permission to carry on this regulated activity is subject to the same requirements and limitations as apply to the firm's permission to advise on investments.

This firm is not a tied agent. Money Laundering Certain firms must protect themselves against money laundering and comply with the Money Laundering Regulations of 2007 This firm is not registered under the Money Laundering Regulations. Insurance Mediation A firm that offers or sells insurance products and services This firm is able to undertake insurance mediation.

full_panel.header: Appointed representatives / tied agents / PSD or EMD agents
full_panel.body: An appointed representative is a firm or individual that can act on behalf of another firm or individual (its 'principal') that is authorised by the PRA and/or FCA. A tied agent can act on behalf of another firm or individual (its 'principal') that is regulated in another country in the European Economic Area (EEA). Appointed representatives and tied agents promote or deal in the products of their principal rather than all products in the market.A PSD or EMD agent is a firm that can act on behalf of another firm (its 'principal') that is authorised or registered by the FCA as a payment or e-money institution.The principal is responsible for the activities of its agents. Previously attached to: ‘Agent status’ shows whether an agent currently has an active relationship with any principal firm. Name  Insurance Mediation  Tied Agent  Firm reference number Effective From Effective To Agent status

An authorised firm will have permission to provide certain regulated products and services. Client Money This firm can hold and/or control customer deposits and client money. It will not usually need separate permission to hold and/or control client money but it must protect this money – it cannot lend it or use it to finance its own business. Specific requirements may change this firm's ability to hold and/or control client money – see below for details. RequirementsRequirements are rules placed on the firm that apply to all of the financial services activities that it can operate. The firm must not, without the FSA's prior written The firm must not, without the FSA's prior written agreement, carry out the following:(i) material movements of assets to its parent or any other companies within its group(ii) material changes to its capital structure or remuneration policy;(iii) the payment of any proposed dividend;(iv any other significant alteration in the composition or quality of the firms assets;(v) permit the use of the firms assets as security for borrowing by any other company; and (vi) enter into any arrangement with a connected person for the provision of goods, services, loans or credit, unless the terms are equivalent to terms had the arrangements been entered into with an unconnected party and in articular the terms must be representative of market value The firm must promptly disclose transfers The firm must promptly disclose to the FSA the transfer and/or payments which do not relate to normal trading activities. The firm must not seek to retain a customer whose The firm must not seek to retain a customer whose contract it requesting to cancel their insurance contract. The firm must cease all regulated activities The firm must cease all regulated activities except for the following activities:(i) Arranging, underwriting and renewing insurance contracts where:(a) the insurance contract is part of a packaged bank account; (a) packaged bank accountbeing an arrangement under which a firm provides a retail banking service as part of apackage which includes access to other goods and services, whether or not a fee ischarged) or(b) the insurance contract is part of a credit card account (a credit card account being anarrangement where a licensee, firm, payment service provider or electronic moneyinsurer enter into a regulated consumer credit agreement with a customer as part of apackage which may include access to other goods and services, whether or not a fee ischarged); or(c) the insurance contract is an ancillary insurance contract (an ancillary insurance contract being aninsurance contract, which is included at the point of inception as part of an insurance package provided byanother firm to a customer and which is not sold to the customer as an additional benefit of the home ormotor insurance package for which the customer must pay an incremental premium).ii) renewals of insurance contracts to customers who have a contract in force on 15 November 2012;(iii) accepting deposits(iv) dealing in investments as principal; (v) administration and performance, including claims handling, of insurance contracts.; and(vi) provision of credit information services. Accepting Deposits Accepting Deposits Customer Type All Investment Type Deposit Limitation Deposit taking activities (Insurance). Advising on investments (except on Pension Transfers and Pension Opt Outs) Advising on investments (except on Pension Transfers and Pension Opt Outs) Customer Type Commercial Retail (Non-Investment Insurance) Investment Type Non-investment insurance contracts Agreeing to carry on a regulated activity Agreeing to carry on a regulated activity Limitation Limited to carry on regulated activities. A firm can apply for a waiver (or change) from our rules or, in some situations, certain discretions set out in articles with European Directives.This table shows the current waivers and discretions we currently hold for this firm.Waivers/ DiscretionsRule/Article NoA2742458P.pdf (pdf /0.089Mb)Group Sup - SII 17.2 A2233608P.pdf (pdf /0.172Mb)Reporting - SII 2.2 (1) Group Sup - SII 17.3 A2401814P.pdf (pdf /0.163Mb)Solvency II Ar.104.(7)

A ‘passport’ enables an authorised firm to provide financial products or services, set up a base, or run its permitted activities in another country in the European Economic Area (EEA). This includes where a firm regulated in another EEA country passports into the UK. FRANCE | GERMANY | IRELAND | PORTUGAL | SPAIN | Please wait... Country Directive Passport Type FRANCE Solvency II Directive Service 13 - General liability 16 - Miscellaneous financial loss 17 - Legal expenses 18 - Assistance 9 - Other damage to property

It will not usually need separate permission to hold and/or control client money but it must protect this money – it cannot lend it or use it to finance its own business. Specific requirements may change this firm's ability to hold and/or control client money – see below for details.

The firm must not, without the FSA's prior written The firm must not, without the FSA's prior written agreement, carry out the following:(i) material movements of assets to its parent or any other companies within its group(ii) material changes to its capital structure or remuneration policy;(iii) the payment of any proposed dividend;(iv any other significant alteration in the composition or quality of the firms assets;(v) permit the use of the firms assets as security for borrowing by any other company; and (vi) enter into any arrangement with a connected person for the provision of goods, services, loans or credit, unless the terms are equivalent to terms had the arrangements been entered into with an unconnected party and in articular the terms must be representative of market value

The firm must cease all regulated activities The firm must cease all regulated activities except for the following activities:(i) Arranging, underwriting and renewing insurance contracts where:(a) the insurance contract is part of a packaged bank account; (a) packaged bank accountbeing an arrangement under which a firm provides a retail banking service as part of apackage which includes access to other goods and services, whether or not a fee ischarged) or(b) the insurance contract is part of a credit card account (a credit card account being anarrangement where a licensee, firm, payment service provider or electronic moneyinsurer enter into a regulated consumer credit agreement with a customer as part of apackage which may include access to other goods and services, whether or not a fee ischarged); or(c) the insurance contract is an ancillary insurance contract (an ancillary insurance contract being aninsurance contract, which is included at the point of inception as part of an insurance package provided byanother firm to a customer and which is not sold to the customer as an additional benefit of the home ormotor insurance package for which the customer must pay an incremental premium).ii) renewals of insurance contracts to customers who have a contract in force on 15 November 2012;(iii) accepting deposits(iv) dealing in investments as principal; (v) administration and performance, including claims handling, of insurance contracts.; and(vi) provision of credit information services.
